title: Distributors
historical_context: This article is part of the early hacking culture, showcasing the distribution methods of hacking zines and the community's reliance on bulletin board systems (BBS) and FTP sites.
target_audience: Hackers, phreakers, and those interested in the history of hacking culture.
short_summary: Mister Sandman introduces the first release of a hacking zine, detailing its distribution methods and inviting others to join the distributor list.
summary:
In this brief article, Mister Sandman announces the inaugural release of a hacking zine, emphasizing the limited distribution channels available at the time. The primary distributor mentioned is the Spanish 29A headquarters, with additional access provided through their homepage and FTP sites. The tone is light-hearted, reflecting the informal nature of the hacker community during this period. Sandman encourages interested parties to reach out via email to join the distributor list, highlighting the collaborative spirit of the early hacking culture.

The article serves as a snapshot of the era's distribution practices, where zines were shared through physical and digital means, fostering a sense of community among hackers and phreakers. It underscores the importance of BBS and FTP sites in disseminating information and resources within the underground scene, making it a relevant read for those interested in the evolution of hacker communication and culture.
